review.title: Continuous Representation of Location for Geolocation and Lexical Dialectology using Mixture Density Networks
review.abstract: We propose a method for embedding two-dimensional locations in a continuous vector space using a neural network-based model incorporating mixtures of Gaussian distributions, presenting two model variants for text-based geolocation and lexical dialectology. Evaluated over Twitter data, the proposed model outperforms conventional regression-based geolocation and provides a better estimate of uncertainty. We also show the effectiveness of the representation for predicting words from location in lexical dialectology, and evaluate it using the DARE dataset.

sections.text: Dimensional positions in a continuous vector space using a neural network-based model with mixtures of Gaussian distributions and two model variants for text-based geolocalization and lexical dialectology. Evaluated using Twitter data, the proposed model surpasses traditional regression-based geolocalization and provides a better estimate of uncertainty. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of representation for predicting words from the position in lexical dialectology and evaluate them using the DARE dataset.

sections.heading: 2.2 Lexical Dialectology
sections.text: The traditional linguistic approach to lexical dialectology is to find the geographical distributions of known contrast terms such as {you, yall, yinz}: (Labov et al., 2005; Nerbonne et al., 2008; Gonc, alves and Sa, 2014; Doyle, 2014; Huang et al., 2015; Nguyen and Eisenstein, appear) This usually involves measuring a large geographically uniform sample of people from different locations and analyzing where each known alternative is used more frequently. Then, the coordinates are pooled heuristically into dialect regions, based on the lexical choices of users in each region relative to the amount of contrast. This processing is very expensive and time-consuming and relies crucially on knowledge of lexical alternatives a priori. For example, they require a prioritized knowledge of the fact that people in different regions of the US and soda use the same type of drinks.

Consequently, it may be a difficult task for the model to learn all the parameters of each sample correctly. sections.heading: 3.5 Continuous Representation of Location
sections.text: Gaussian mixtures are usually used as an output layer in neural networks (such as MDN) for inverse regression problems. We extend their application by using them as input representation when the input is a multidimensional continuous variable. Problems such as lexical dialectology are real 2D coordinates, and the goal is to predict dialectology words from a given location. Small differences in longitude and latitude can lead to large shifts in language usage (e.g. in regions such as Switzerland or Gibraltar). A better solution is to use a K component Gaussian compound representation of the place where micro and area indications are divided in the classification, with the significant downside that the model is unable to learn / fine-tune regions on a data-based basis. A better solution is to use a K component Gaussian compound representation of the location where microparameters are then used as input parameters.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments
sections.text: We apply the two described MDN models to two widely used geotagged Twitter datasets for localization and compare the results with state-of-the-art classification and regression baselines. We also use the mixture of Gaussian spatial representation to predict dialect terms based on coordinates.

sections.heading: 4.1 Data
sections.text: In our experiments, we use two existing Twitter user geolocation datasets: (1) GEOTEXT (Eisenstein et al., 2010) and (2) TWITTER-US (Roller et al., 2012). Each dataset has fixed training, development and test partitions, and a user is represented by the concatenation of his tweets and labeled with the latitude and longitude of the first geotagged tweet.2 GEOTEXT and TWITTER-US cover the continental US with 9k, 449k users. DARE is a dialect term dataset that appears from the dialect dictionary of American Regional English (Cassidy, 1985) by Rahimi et al. DARE consists of dialect regions, terms, and the meaning of each term.4 It represents the aggregation of a number of dialect surveys in different regions of the USA.

sections.heading: 4.2 Geolocation
sections.text: We use a three-layer neural network, as shown in Figure 1a, where the input is removed from a user's l2 normalized vocabulary model with stop words, @ - mentions, and words with a document frequency of less than 10. Input is fed into a hidden layer with tanh nonlinearity, which produces the output of the network (without applied nonlinearity). The output is the capture of Gaussian mixing parameters (µ, Σ, π) from MDN. For prediction, the micron of the mixing component is selected, which has the highest probability within the mixing component. In the case of MDN-SHARED, the output is only a vector with size K, but the output layer contains additional global parameters µ and хlat (σlat, сlon, сlon, м), which are split between all samples. sections.heading: 4.3 Lexical Dialectology
sections.text: To predict dialect words from a location, we use a 4-layer neural network as shown in Figure 1b. Input is a latitude / longitude coordinate, the first hidden layer is a Gaussian mixture with K components that has a probability distribution across the vocabulary and produces a probability for each component as an activation function, the second hidden layer with tanh nonlinearity captures the association between different Gaussians, and the output is a SoftMax layer that leads to a probability distribution across the vocabulary. For a user label, we use an l1 normalized word set that represents its text content, and use binary tf and idf for weighting terms. The model should learn to predict the probability distribution across the vocabulary and thus be able to determine dialect words with a higher probability than the ratio of words to words.

sections.heading: 5.1 Geolocation
sections.text: The performance of regression, MDN and MDN-SHARED, as well as several state-of-the-art classification models, is shown in Table 2. MDN and MDN-SHARED models perform significantly better than regression and achieve competitive or slightly worse results than the classification models, but offer uncertainty over the entire production area. Geographical error distribution for MDN-SHARED across the development group of TWITTER-US is shown in Figure 3, indicating larger errors in the Midwest and particularly in the North Pacific regions (e.g. Oregon).

sections.heading: 5.2 Dialectology
sections.text: The confusion of the lexical dialect model using Gaussian mixing representation (MDN layer) is 840 for the 54k vocabulary of the TWITTER-US dataset, 1% lower than with a similar network architecture with a tanh hidden layer (tanh layer), which is not a significant improvement. We also evaluated the model using Recall at at k and compared it with the tanh layer model, which in turn competes with tanh layer, but has the advantage of learning dialect regions at the same time. As the DARE dialect regions are not widely used in Twitter, many of the words, despite their size, are not covered in our dataset. However, our model is capable of retrieving dialect regions that are clearly associated with regions.
